titleText.ttltext: Observational studies on non-specific effects (NSE) of diphtheria-tetanus-pertussis @hit_startvaccination@hit_end (DTP) in low-income countries: Assessing the impact of bias and confounding by using @hit_startmeta@hit_end-regression

paras: Background: It has been suggested that @hit_startvaccines@hit_end have NSE on morbidity and mortality due to infections others than those targeted by the @hit_startvaccine@hit_end or for unknown reasons. Some observational studies showed increased relative risks (RR) of all-cause mortality with DTP containing a whole-cell pertussis component. Based on a recent review and @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end of selected studies (Higgins, BMJ 2016), the WHO concluded that the results are inconsistent. However, the WHO @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end and its conclusions were challenged. Objectives: To assess the potential impact of bias and confounding on the estimated RR of all-cause mortality after DTP. Methods: Based on methodological considerations on study design and @hit_startanalysis@hit_end, we systematically assessed all 17 DTP studies from the WHO review for risk of selection bias, exposure and outcome misclassification, confounding, and differential co-interventions with other @hit_startvaccines@hit_end including co-administration. We performed @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analyses@hit_end on all studies and complemented with @hit_startmeta@hit_end-regression, including the assessed sources of bias and confounding as covariates. Permutation tests were used to control the risk of false positives. Results are expressed as relative risk ratios (RRRs), with RRR >1 indicating that the RR estimate is larger when the covariate is present, compared with absent. Uni- and multi-variable @hit_startmeta@hit_end-regressions were performed. Results: The overall RR of all-cause mortality after DTP @hit_startvaccination@hit_end based on all studies was 1.32 (95% CI: 0.83-2.08). Based on uni-variable @hit_startmeta@hit_end-regression, the highest RR estimate was for studies conducted in Africa (RRR = 3.16, p = 0.002), studies using the landmark approach (RRR = 2.97, p = 0.015) and studies at high risk of selection bias (RRR = 2.28, p = 0.039), exposure misclassification (RRR = 2.28, p = 0.05) and confounding (RRR = 2.65, p = 0.052). These covariates cluster in studies from Africa (n = 11) and their individual impact could not be disentangled using multi-variable regression. Conclusions: Our results suggest that several potential sources of bias and confounding are significantly associated with increased RR of allcause mortality after DTP. Bias and confounding can therefore not be ruled out as an explanation of the increased RR. Higher quality data are needed for a robust evaluation of NSE of DTP studies.

titleText.ttltext: Efficacy, effectiveness and safety of @hit_startvaccination@hit_end against human papillomavirus in males: A @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end

paras: Background: Human papillomavirus (HPV) @hit_startvaccination@hit_end is safe and effective in preventing cervical cancer in females. As HPV infections can also induce cancers of the anus, penis and oral cavity, male @hit_startvaccination@hit_end is also advocated, but @hit_startsystematic reviews@hit_end on efficacy and safety in males are lacking. Methods: We performed a @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end on the efficacy, effectiveness and safety of HPV @hit_startvaccination@hit_end in males of any age. @hit_startMEDLINE@hit_end, @hit_startEmbase@hit_end, the @hit_startCochrane@hit_end Central Register of Controlled Trials and ClinicalTrials.gov were searched from inception to April 2017. Results: We identified 5196 articles and seven studies (four randomized controlled trials (RCTs), three non-randomized studies) were included, comprising a total of 5294 participants. @hit_startVaccine@hit_end efficacy against at least 6-month persisting anogenital HPV 16 infections was 46.9% (95% confidence interval (CI) 28.6-60.8%), whereas efficacy against persisting oral infections was 88% (2-98%). A @hit_startvaccine@hit_end efficacy of 61.9% (21.4-82.8%) and 46.8% (- 20 to -77.9%) was observed against @hit_startanal@hit_end intraepithelial neoplasia grade 2 and grade 3 lesions, respectively. No meaningful estimates were available on @hit_startvaccine@hit_end efficacy or effectiveness against penile intraepithelial neoplasia grade 2 or 3, and no data were identified for @hit_startanal@hit_end, penile or head and neck squamous cell cancer. In participants who were HPV-seronegative and PCR-negative at enrolment, efficacy against all outcomes was higher as compared to seropositive and/or PCR-positive individuals. Risk of bias was low in three RCTs and high in one, while the three non-randomized studies were at serious to critical risk of bias. Grading of Recommendations Assessment, Development and Evaluation evidence quality was moderate to low for most outcomes. Conclusions: HPV @hit_startvaccination@hit_end in males is moderately effective against persistent anogenital HPV infection and high-grade @hit_startanal@hit_end intraepithelial lesions in studies where the population consists mainly of HPV-infected males. @hit_startVaccine@hit_end effectiveness was high in study groups comprising HPV-naïve males. This supports a recommendation for @hit_startvaccination@hit_end of boys before the onset of sexual activity with the goal of establishing optimal @hit_startvaccine@hit_end@hit_start-induced@hit_end protection. Mathematical modelling studies will still be needed to assess the effects of adding males to existing HPV @hit_startvaccination@hit_end programs in females.

titleText.ttltext: Adjuvant therapy for advanced renal cell carcinoma

organizations: Department of Urology, The University of Texas MD Anderson Cancer Center

abstracts.publisherCopyright: © 2018, © 2018 Informa UK Limited, trading as Taylor & Francis Group.
paras: Introduction: Locally advanced, non-metastatic renal cell carcinoma (RCC) is conventionally managed with surgery. However, patients are at a high risk of RCC recurrence and have poor survival outcomes. An effective adjuvant systemic treatment is needed to improve on these outcomes. Targeted molecular and immune-based therapies have been investigated, or are under investigation, but their role in this setting remains unclear. Areas covered: A comprehensive search of @hit_startPubMed@hit_end and ClinicalTrials.gov was performed for relevant literature. The following topics pertinent to adjuvant therapy in RCC were evaluated: strategies for patient selection, cytokine-based immunotherapy, @hit_startvaccine@hit_end therapy, VEGF and non-VEGF targeted molecular agents, and immune checkpoint inhibitors. Expert commentary: Strong evidence for the incorporation of adjuvant therapy in high-risk RCC is lacking. Multiple targeted molecular therapies have been examined with only one approved for use. Genetic and molecular-based prognostic models are needed to determine who may benefit from adjuvant therapy. Developing adjuvant therapy strategies in the future depends on the results of important ongoing trials with immunotherapy and targeted agents.

titleText.ttltext: Pharmacologic Modulation of Human @hit_startImmunity@hit_end in the Era of Immuno-oncology: Something Old, Something New

organizations: Department of Medical Oncology, Mayo Clinic

abstracts.publisherCopyright: © 2018 Mayo Foundation for Medical Education and Research
paras: The concept of exploiting the immune system to treat cancer forms the basis of immuno-oncology. Since its birth in the late 1800s, immuno-oncology, or cancer immunotherapy, has come a long way. With better understanding of the complex relationship between tumor and the immune system, we have been able to explore and develop various modalities of anticancer therapies. In this review, we summarize the main strategies of immunotherapy that are available today: monoclonal antibodies, anticancer @hit_startvaccines@hit_end, cytokines, and adoptive T-cell therapy. We also highlight the unique set of adverse effects associated with modern immunotherapy and propose nonsteroidal immunomodulators and anticytokine antibodies as treatment options for toxicities. The future of immuno-oncology is discussed, including combination therapy, drug-antibody conjugates, epigenetic drugs, using nanoparticles for drug delivery, new antigen discovery, and developing biomarkers to assess treatment responses. A data search was conducted using @hit_startPubMed@hit_end and included studies published through November 1, 2017. Search terms used include cancer immunotherapy, pembrolizumab, ipilimumab, nivolumab, PD-1 inhibitors, PD-L1 inhibitors, checkpoint inhibitors, anticancer @hit_startvaccines@hit_end, TVEC, and adoptive cell therapy.

titleText.ttltext: Middle east respiratory syndrome (MERS): A @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end

organizations: Department of Pharmacy Practice, Anwarul Uloom College of Pharmacy

abstracts.publisherCopyright: © 2013 are reserved by International Journal of Pharmaceutical Sciences and Research.
paras: The first case of middle east respiratory syndrome (MERS) was identified in a mid-aged Saudi Arabian resident in 2012. The syndrome is @hit_startanalogous@hit_end to severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) in its clinical course, with a male predominance in incidence. MERS virus is disseminated as a result of close proximity of people to camels, person to person transmission being uncommon and confined to hospital settings. The incubation period usually lasts for 2 - 14 days. MERS-CoV appears to be an enzootic virus, tracing its origin to bats, whereas camels may act as intermediate hosts. Typical flu-like symptoms are observed, which include pyrexia, myalgia, apnoea and cough. Symptoms advance over time leading to multiple organ failure, septic shock and eventually death. Diagnosis can be done with the aid of recombinant IgA and IgG ELISAs, and other specific assays such as upE and real-time Reverse Transcription (rt-RT) PCR assay. Currently, neither an authorized @hit_startvaccine@hit_end nor a definitive treatment is available for human use. However, adenosine deaminase, mycophenolic acid (MPA), cyclosporine A, nelfinavir, lopinavir, combination of IFN-α2b and ribavirin are underway to attain recognition as specific therapies. The following review summarizes the pharmacotherapy and management options for healthcare workers and preventive strategies for susceptible groups. Our review demonstrates that there exists some relation of the virus with seasonal variability, peculiarly in months from May to September.

titleText.ttltext: Influenza @hit_startvaccination@hit_end for HIV-positive people: @hit_startSystematic review@hit_end and network @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end

organizations: Centre for Health Evaluation and Outcome Sciences, St. Paul's Hospital

paras: Background: People with Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) are highly susceptible to influenza-related morbidity and mortality. In order to assess comparative efficacy of influenza @hit_startvaccine@hit_end strategies among HIV-positive people, we performed a @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end and Bayesian network @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end (NMA). Methods: In this @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end, we searched @hit_startMEDLINE@hit_end, @hit_startEMBASE@hit_end, @hit_startCochrane@hit_end Central Register of Controlled Trials, @hit_startCochrane@hit_end Database of @hit_startSystematic Reviews@hit_end, and @hit_startCINAHL@hit_end between 1946 and July 2015 for randomized controlled trials (RCTs) on influenza @hit_startvaccines@hit_end for HIV-positive adults reporting seroconversion or seroprotection outcomes. The NMAs were conducted within a Bayesian framework and logistic models were used for comparing the effect of the @hit_startvaccine@hit_end strategies on the two outcomes. Results: A total of 1957 publications were identified, 143 were selected for full review, and 13 RCTs were included in our final @hit_startanalysis@hit_end. Fourteen separate NMAs were conducted by outcomes, @hit_startvaccine@hit_end strain, and different outcome measurement timepoints. For example, compared with the 15 μg single @hit_startvaccine@hit_end strategy, the odds ratio was the highest for the adjuvant 7.5 μg booster strategy (2.99 [95% credible interval 1.18–7.66]) when comparing seroconversion for H1N1 at 14–41 days after the last dose of @hit_startvaccination@hit_end and for the 60 μg single strategy (2.33 [1.31–4.18]) when comparing seroconversion for strain B. Conclusions: The adjuvant 7.5 μg booster and 60 μg single @hit_startvaccine@hit_end strategies provided better seroconversion and seroprotection outcomes. These findings have important implications for national and international guidelines for influenza @hit_startvaccination@hit_end for HIV-positive people and future research.

titleText.ttltext: Post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) for rabies with purified chick embryo cell @hit_startvaccine@hit_end: a @hit_startsystematic literature review@hit_end and @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end

abstracts.publisherCopyright: © 2018, © 2018 Informa UK Limited, trading as Taylor & Francis Group.
paras: Introduction: Fifteen million people each year receive post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) to prevent rabies, yet the disease remains neglected and highly under-reported. Areas covered: In this @hit_startsystematic literature review@hit_end, we assessed the immunogenicity, efficacy, and safety of a purified chick embryo cell-culture rabies @hit_startvaccine@hit_end (PCECV) for PEP against rabies by intramuscular (IM) or intradermal (ID) administration. We performed @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analyses@hit_end to compare immunogenicity according to the route of @hit_startvaccine@hit_end administration, study population, and PEP regimen, such as number of doses, and concomitant rabies immunoglobulin. Expert commentary: There were 54 estimates of immune responses to @hit_startvaccination@hit_end, which showed that in the overall population, after starting PEP with PCECV by the IM or ID route (≥2.5 IU per dose), almost all individuals had rabies virus neutralizing antibody (RVNA) titers above the World Health Organization (WHO) recommended serological threshold for an adequate immune response to @hit_startvaccination@hit_end (RVNA ≥0.5 IU/ml by day 14). In the overall population, PCECV had an acceptable safety profile. However, given that there are 59,000 human rabies deaths reported annually, the challenge is to improve access to PCECV for PEP against human rabies.

titleText.ttltext: ESCMID Study Group for Infections in Compromised Hosts (ESGICH) Consensus Document on the safety of targeted and biological therapies: an infectious diseases perspective (Soluble immune effector molecules [II]: agents targeting interleukins, immunoglobulins and complement factors)

organizations: Division of Infectious Diseases, Oregon Health and Science University

abstracts.publisherCopyright: © 2018 European Society of Clinical Microbiology and Infectious Diseases
paras: Background: The present review is part of the ESCMID Study Group for Infections in Compromised Hosts (ESGICH) Consensus Document on the safety of targeted and biological therapies. Aims: To review, from an Infectious Diseases perspective, the safety profile of agents targeting interleukins, immunoglobulins and complement factors and to suggest preventive recommendations. Sources: Computer-based @hit_startMEDLINE@hit_end searches with MeSH terms pertaining to each agent or therapeutic family. Content: Patients receiving interleukin-1 (IL-1) -targeted (anakinra, canakinumab or rilonacept) or IL-5-targeted (mepolizumab) agents have a moderate risk of infection and no specific prevention strategies are recommended. The use of IL-6/IL-6 receptor-targeted agents (tocilizumab and siltuximab) is associated with a risk increase similar to that observed with anti-tumour necrosis factor-α agents. IL-12/23-targeted agents (ustekinumab) do not seem to pose a meaningful risk of infection, although screening for latent tuberculosis infection may be considered and antiviral prophylaxis should be given to hepatitis B surface antigen-positive patients. Therapy with IL-17-targeted agents (secukinumab, brodalumab and ixekizumab) may result in the development of mild-to-moderate mucocutaneous candidiasis. Pre-treatment screening for Strongyloides stercoralis and other geohelminths should be considered in patients who come from areas where these are endemic who are receiving IgE-targeted agents (omalizumab). C5-targeted agents (eculizumab) are associated with a markedly increased risk of infection due to encapsulated bacteria, particularly Neisseria spp. Meningococcal @hit_startvaccination@hit_end and chemoprophylaxis must be administered 2–4 weeks before initiating eculizumab. Patients with high-risk behaviours and their partners should also be screened for gonococcal infection. Implications: Preventive strategies are particularly encouraged to minimize the occurrence of neisserial infection associated with eculizumab.

titleText.ttltext: Creating evidence basis to monitor progress of viral hepatitis elimination goals in Germany

organizations: Translational Epidemiology, Department for Infectious Disease Epidemiology

paras: Background: Prevalence of viral hepatitis B, C and D is low in Germany. However, the burden of disease can be high among vulnerable groups. There is currently no overview of the scientific evidence regarding epidemiological situation in the general population and vulnerable groups in Germany. We performed a @hit_startsystematic literature review@hit_end to understand the baseline epidemiological situation in the light of viral hepatitis elimination goals in Germany, and to identify knowledge gaps and research needs. Methods: The protocol of the @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end was prepared fol-lowing PRISMA statement guidelines and in line with the @hit_startCochrane@hit_end Collaboration. Relevant search terms were used to identify eligible studies reporting on burden of disease (prevalence, incidence, transmission routes, distribution of genotypes, co-infections, quality of life and outcome of infection) and management (@hit_startvaccination@hit_end, diagnosis, therapy and liver transplantation) of viral hepatitis B, C and D. We searched the online databases @hit_startEmbase@hit_end, @hit_startPubMed@hit_end, Europe PMC, Scopus and Base Bielefeld and CC Med for references published between January 2005 and March 2017. Only studies with original data were included. References were screened for relevance and eligibility by two independent reviewers; first on the level of article title and abstract, later on the level of the full text. Results: We identified in total 10.956 references; 601 full text ref-erences were identified in first screening of which 90 were eligible for extraction. As of 19@sup_beginth@sup_end of February 2018 we have extracted 83 references (63, 57 and 10 describing hepatitis B, C and D, respectively) representing 302 outcomes: 221 on burden of disease (94 prevalence, 7 incidence, 22 transmission routes, 15 distribution of genotypes, 34 co-infections, 66 outcome of infection, 3 quality of life) and 81 described management (33 @hit_startvaccination@hit_end coverage, 10 di-agnosis, 23 therapy, 15 liver transplantation). The population groups include the general population, a range of clinical populations, intravenous drug users, men who have sex with men, healthcare workers and migrants. Compilation and @hit_startanalysis@hit_end of extracted results is ongoing. Conclusions: We created a comprehensive evidence-based over-view on the current epidemiological situation of viral hepatitis in Germany. Based on ongoing @hit_startanalysis@hit_end of the extracted data we will be able to identify knowledge gaps for further research and establish baseline for future monitoring of viral hepatitis elimination goals in Germany.

titleText.ttltext: Estimating the annual attack rate of seasonal influenza among unvaccinated individuals: A @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end and @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end

paras: Introduction: Seasonal influenza affects millions of people globally each year, causing significant morbidity and mortality. However, there remains substantial uncertainty about the attack rate (incidence) of influenza, particularly in unvaccinated individuals. Methods: We undertook a @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end of @hit_startvaccine@hit_end randomised controlled trials (RCTs) that reported on laboratory-confirmed seasonal influenza in the placebo arm. We calculated the influenza attack rate from included studies as the number of laboratory-confirmed positive seasonal influenza cases in the placebo arm divided by the total number of subjects in this arm. A random effects @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end was conducted to estimate the influenza attack rate among unvaccinated individuals (both symptomatic only as well as symptomatic and asymptomatic combined). Results: We included 32 RCTs that had a total of 13,329 participants. The pooled estimates for symptomatic influenza were 12.7% (95%CI 8.5%, 18.6%) for children (<18 years), 4.4% (95%CI 3.0%, 6.3%) for adults, and 7.2% (95%CI 4.3%, 12.0%) for older people (65 years and above). The pooled estimates for symptomatic and asymptomatic influenza combined for all influenza were 22.5% (95%CI 9.0%, 46.0%) for children and 10.7% (95%CI 4.5%, 23.2%) for adults. Only one study was identified for symptomatic and asymptomatic combined in older people which had a rate of 8.8% (95%CI 7.0%, 10.8%). There was substantial heterogeneity between studies. Conclusion: Overall, we found that approximately 1 in 5 unvaccinated children and 1 in 10 unvaccinated adults were estimated to be infected by seasonal influenza annually, with rates of symptomatic influenza roughly half of these estimates. Our findings help to establish the background risk of seasonal influenza infection in unvaccinated individuals.

titleText.ttltext: A @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end and @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end of the effects of educating parents on the benefits and schedules of childhood @hit_startvaccinations@hit_end in low and middle-income countries

organizations: Cochrane South Africa, South African Medical Research Council, Francie van Zijl Drive

abstracts.publisherCopyright: © 2018 Lungeni Auguy Lukusa, Valantine Ngum Ndze, Nyanyiwe Masingi Mbeye, and Charles Shey Wiysonge. Published with license by Taylor & Francis.
paras: Public health benefits of childhood @hit_startvaccinations@hit_end risk being derailed by low @hit_startvaccination@hit_end coverage in low and middle-income countries. One reason for the low coverage is poor parental knowledge of the importance of completing @hit_startvaccination@hit_end schedules. We therefore assessed the effects on childhood @hit_startvaccination@hit_end coverage, of educating parents and other persons assuming the parental role. We prospectively registered the @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end, published the protocol, and used standard @hit_startCochrane@hit_end methods to collect and synthesise the evidence. We found six eligible randomised trials with 4248 participants. Three trials assessed health-facility based education of mothers on the importance of completing @hit_startvaccination@hit_end schedules; immediately after birth and three months later (one study) or during the first @hit_startvaccination@hit_end visit (two studies). The other trials assessed community-based education, including information campaigns on the importance of @hit_startvaccines@hit_end using audiotaped presentations and leaflet distributions (one study); structured group discussions on benefits and costs of childhood @hit_startvaccination@hit_end and local action plans for improving @hit_startvaccine@hit_end uptake (one study); and home-based information sessions using graphic cards showing benefits and costs of childhood @hit_startvaccinations@hit_end and location of @hit_startvaccination@hit_end centres (one study). Combining the data shows that these interventions lead to substantial improvements in childhood @hit_startvaccination@hit_end coverage (relative increase 36%, 95% confidence interval 14% to 62%). There was no difference between the effects of community-based and facility-based education. Therefore, education in communities and health facilities on the importance of childhood @hit_startvaccinations@hit_end should be integrated into all @hit_startvaccination@hit_end programmes in low and middle-income countries; accompanied by robust monitoring of impacts and use of data for action.

titleText.ttltext: Human papillomavirus @hit_startvaccine@hit_end acceptability and decision-making among adolescent boys and parents: A @hit_startmeta@hit_end-ethnography of qualitative studies

organizations: Factor-Inwentash Faculty of Social Work, University of Toronto

paras: Objective: Genital warts and human papillomavirus (HPV)-associated cancers in men can be substantially reduced through HPV @hit_startvaccination@hit_end; yet, globally, HPV @hit_startvaccine@hit_end uptake among boys remains low. This @hit_startmeta@hit_end-ethnography synthesizes qualitative studies to understand, in-depth, HPV @hit_startvaccine@hit_end acceptability and decision-making among adolescent boys and/or their parents. Methods: A systematic search identified qualitative studies examining HPV @hit_startvaccines@hit_end from the perspectives of boys and/or boys’ parents. The Consolidated Criteria for Reporting Qualitative Research (COREQ) 32-item checklist was used to assess quality of reporting. Using @hit_startmeta@hit_end-ethnographic techniques, we conducted a structured and iterative process of data @hit_startanalysis@hit_end, coded original studies, and then developed descriptive and @hit_startanalytic@hit_end themes to synthesize the findings. Results: Review of 15 eligible studies (n = 3362 parents, n = 39 boys) revealed multilevel factors that influence HPV @hit_startvaccine@hit_end acceptability and decision-making among adolescent boys and their parents: (1) individual, e.g., low HPV @hit_startvaccine@hit_end knowledge/awareness, (2) interpersonal, e.g., key relationships between parents, sons, and healthcare providers (HCP), (3) community/societal, e.g., parental duty to protect, and (4) systemic, e.g., HPV @hit_startvaccine@hit_end messaging. Parents generally accepted adolescent boys’ sexuality and the need for @hit_startvaccination@hit_end, motivated by wanting to protect their sons from HPV and HPV-associated cancers, and valued HCP-initiated discussion and recommendation. Acceptability was mitigated by low awareness/knowledge of HPV @hit_startvaccines@hit_end and low perceived benefits for boys, lack of HCP-initiated discussion, out-of-pocket costs, multiple doses, stigma, and mixed messages about HPV. Conclusions: Multilevel factors influence HPV @hit_startvaccine@hit_end acceptability and decision-making among parents and their adolescent sons. Providing clear and unambiguous messages about HPV @hit_startvaccines@hit_end—for whom (boys and girls), for what (genital warts and cancers in men), and when (before sexual debut)—through increased HCP-initiated discussion and targeted public health campaigns may support HPV @hit_startvaccine@hit_end uptake among boys. Future research should consistently disaggregate findings by sex of child and parent, and explore effective messaging tailored for boys and parents.

titleText.ttltext: Medications and Prescribing Patterns as Factors Associated with Hospitalizations from Long-Term Care Facilities: A @hit_startSystematic Review@hit_end

organizations: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences, Centre for Medicine Use and Safety, Monash University

abstracts.publisherCopyright: © 2018, Springer International Publishing AG, part of Springer Nature.
paras: Background: Residents of long-term care facilities (LTCFs) are at high risk of hospitalization. Medications are a potentially modifiable risk factor for hospitalizations. Objective: Our objective was to @hit_startsystematically review@hit_end the association between medications or prescribing patterns and hospitalizations from LTCFs. Methods: We searched @hit_startMEDLINE@hit_end, @hit_startEmbase@hit_end, Cumulative Index to Nursing and Allied Health Literature (@hit_startCINAHL@hit_end) and International Pharmaceutical Abstracts (IPA) from inception to August 2017 for longitudinal studies reporting associations between medications or prescribing patterns and hospitalizations. Two independent investigators completed the study selection, data extraction and quality assessment using the Joanna Briggs Institute Critical Appraisal Tools. Results: Three randomized controlled trials (RCTs), 22 cohort studies, five case–control studies, one case-time-control study and one case-crossover study, investigating 13 different medication classes and two prescribing patterns were included. An RCT demonstrated that high-dose influenza @hit_startvaccination@hit_end reduced all-cause hospitalization compared with standard-dose @hit_startvaccination@hit_end (risk ratio [RR] 0.93; 95% confidence interval [CI] 0.88–0.98). Another RCT found no difference in hospitalization rates between oseltamivir as influenza treatment and oseltamivir as treatment plus prophylaxis (treatment = 4.7%, treatment and prophylaxis = 3.5%; p = 0.7). The third RCT found no difference between multivitamin/mineral supplementation and hospitalization (odds ratio [OR] 0.94; 95% CI 0.74–1.20) or emergency department visits (OR 1.05; 95% CI 0.76–1.47). Two cohort studies demonstrated influenza @hit_startvaccination@hit_end reduced hospitalization. Four studies suggested polypharmacy and potentially inappropriate medications (PIMs) increased all-cause hospitalization. However, associations between polypharmacy (two studies), PIMs (one study) and fall-related hospitalizations were inconsistent. Inconsistent associations were found between psychotropic medications with all-cause and cause-specific hospitalizations (11 studies). Warfarin, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, pantoprazole and vinpocetine but not long-term acetylsalicylic acid (aspirin), statins, trimetazidine, digoxin or β-blockers were associated with all-cause or cause-specific hospitalizations in single studies of specific resident populations. Most cohort studies assessed prevalent rather than incident medication exposure, and no studies considered time-varying medication use. Conclusion: High-quality evidence suggests influenza @hit_startvaccination@hit_end reduces hospitalization. Polypharmacy and PIMs are consistently associated with increased all-cause hospitalization.

titleText.ttltext: Hepatitis B virus (HBV) @hit_startvaccine@hit_end in pregnancy and impact on pregnancy outcome

paras: Objectives: Studies have demonstrated the effectiveness of HBV @hit_startvaccination@hit_end in pregnancy to reduce risk of transmission, but the risk/benefit of HBV @hit_startvaccination@hit_end in pregnancy has not been fully elucidated due to limited data on pregnancy outcomes. This study evaluated data on HBV @hit_startvaccination@hit_end in pregnancy and impact on pregnancy outcomes. Methods: @hit_startMEDLINE@hit_end was searched in Jan 2018 using the search terms: hepatitis B @hit_startvaccine@hit_end, pregnancy, major congenital malformations (MCMs), preterm birth, spontaneous abortion (SAB), and fetal/neonatal death. The search identified 1 RCT, 5 prospective cohort studies, and 1 @hit_startVaccine@hit_end Adverse Event Reporting System (VAERS) study; 5 of 7 studies were conducted in the 1980's-90's. Results: The RCT and 2 cohort studies examined recombinant HBV @hit_startvaccines@hit_end in 284 pregnant women. @hit_startVaccination@hit_end occurred in the 1st trimester in the cohort studies and 3rd trimester in the RCT. No MCMs and 1 SAB were reported. The preterm birth rate was comparable to general population rates. The other 3 cohort studies examined plasma-derived HBV @hit_startvaccines@hit_end in 97 pregnant women. @hit_startVaccination@hit_end occurred in the 1st trimester in 1 study and 2nd/3rd trimester in the other 2. No MCMs, SABs, or preterm births were reported. The stillbirth rate was comparable to the comparator (1.4 vs 1.2). The VAERS study included 192 pregnant women receiving HBV @hit_startvaccines@hit_end from 1990-2015. Most were @hit_startvaccinated@hit_end in the 1st trimester and 110 adverse events were reported, including the following pregnancy-related events: 5 unique MCMs, 23 SABs, 1 neonatal death, 2 stillbirths, and 7 preterm births. Conclusions: The majority of prospective studies identified are old, have limited sample sizes, and inappropriate exposure windows. The VAERS study is recent but has limitations (recall bias, inconsistent data, lack of denominator data) due to the spontaneous/ voluntary nature of the reporting of adverse events. While the data from these limited studies are reassuring, more research is needed.

event.name: 23rd Annual Meeting of the International Society for Pharmacoeconomics and Outcomes Research, ISPOR 2018

titleText.ttltext: Targeted therapies in the management of locally advanced and metastatic pancreatic cancer: A @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end

organizations: Vascular Biology and Translational Research, School of Medical Sciences, University of New South Wales

paras: Pancreatic cancer has a dismal prognosis particularly in patients presenting with unresectable tumors. We performed a bibliometric @hit_startanalysis@hit_end of clinical trials for pancreatic cancer conducted between 2014-2016 focusing on patients that presented with unresectable (locally advanced or metastatic) tumors. We discuss a range of studies that employed FOLFIRINOX, the gemcitabine + nab-paclitaxel combination and studies that used molecularly-targeted therapy. Major areas of focus have been dual targeting of EGFR and VEGFR, immunotherapy or a multimodal approach - combining chemotherapy with radiotherapy. We also point out the need for molecular selection for low prevalence subtypes. Key insights sourced from these pivotal trials should improve clinical outcomes for this devastating cancer.

titleText.ttltext: Incidence of narcolepsy after H1N1 influenza and @hit_startvaccinations@hit_end: @hit_startSystematic review@hit_end and @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end

organizations: Central Finland Central Hospital, Department of Neurology

paras: An increased incidence of narcolepsy was seen in many countries after the pandemic H1N1 influenza @hit_startvaccination@hit_end campaign in 2009–2010. The H1N1 @hit_startvaccine@hit_end – narcolepsy connection is based on observational studies that are prone to various biases, e.g., confounding by H1N1 infection, and ascertainment, recall and selection biases. A direct pathogenic link has, however, remained elusive. We conducted a @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end and @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end to @hit_startanalyze@hit_end the magnitude of H1N1 @hit_startvaccination@hit_end related risk and to examine if there was any association with H1N1 infection itself. We searched all articles from @hit_startPubMed@hit_end, Web of Science and Scopus, and other relevant sources reporting the incidence and risk of post-@hit_startvaccine@hit_end narcolepsy. In our paper, we show that the risk appears to be limited to only one @hit_startvaccine@hit_end (Pandemrix@sup_begin®@sup_end). During the first year after @hit_startvaccination@hit_end, the relative risk of narcolepsy was increased 5 to 14-fold in children and adolescents and 2 to 7-fold in adults. The @hit_startvaccine@hit_end attributable risk in children and adolescents was around 1 per 18,400 @hit_startvaccine@hit_end doses. Studies from Finland and Sweden also appear to demonstrate an extended risk of narcolepsy into the second year following @hit_startvaccination@hit_end, but such conclusions should be interpreted with a word of caution due to possible biases. Benefits of @hit_startimmunization@hit_end outweigh the risk of @hit_startvaccination@hit_end@hit_start-associated@hit_end narcolepsy, which remains a rare disease.

titleText.ttltext: Immunomodulation in novel cancer therapies: The role of CC-motif chemokine ligand 21 and programmed cell Death Protein 1

paras: Purpose/Objective(s): Investigations in immunomodulating therapies for cancer treatment over the past 20 years have flourished. Given the complex tumor microenvironment and differential signaling pathways, a wide variety of potential targeting mechanisms have come to attention. Herein, we review the immunomodulating potential of Chemokine 21 (CCL-21) in preclinical and clinical studies, as well as examine the novel multifaceted immune-based treatments in advanced head and neck cancer. Materials/Methods: A @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end of the CC-motif Chemokine Ligand 21 in order to identify the inflammatory historical background, role in cancer, preclinical investigations, and novel polymer-based delivery system was undertaken. Additionally, current ongoing clinical trials were evaluated for impact. Finally, the role of CCL-21 in the head and neck cancer population is reviewed and future pathways discussed. Results: The role of CCL-21 is critical in promoting DC homing and Tlymphocyte activation. Tumor antigen presentation is significantly amplified both locally and peripherally following introduction of CCL- 21. The results of the phase 1 studies in lung cancer and melanoma are promising. CCL21 is important in the formation of tertiary lymphoid structures and their presence in tumors is associated with favorable immune responses. Conclusion: Based on the findings on CCL21, it is anticipated that the rational combination with immune checkpoint blockade therapy will improve the antitumor benefit of this chemokine in a broad range of solid tumors with low tumor infiltrating lymphocyte frequency (TIL). Future studies could assess the combined efficacy of CCL21-based regimens with immune checkpoint blockade therapy in various solid tumors as immune activation by CCL21 leads to upregulation of PD-1 on activated T cells. CCL21-based therapeutic @hit_startvaccination@hit_end approaches will prove beneficial for tumors that are not accessible for intratumoral administration of CCL21. Furthermore, material and nanoparticle engineering provides several attractive strategies to design more potent CCL21 immunotherapy.

titleText.ttltext: Parents' uptake of human papillomavirus @hit_startvaccines@hit_end for their children: A @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end and @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end of observational studies

organizations: Centre for Applied Social Research, Factor-Inwentash Faculty of Social Work, University of Toronto

paras: Objective To examine factors associated with parents' uptake of human papillomavirus (HPV) @hit_startvaccines@hit_end for their children. Design @hit_startSystematic review@hit_end and @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end. Data sources @hit_startCochrane@hit_end Library, AIDSLINE, @hit_startCINAHL@hit_end, @hit_startEMBASE@hit_end, @hit_startPsycINFO@hit_end, Social Sciences Abstracts, Ovid @hit_startMEDLINE@hit_end, Scholars Portal, Social Sciences Citation Index and Dissertation Abstracts International from inception through November 2017. Methods We included studies that sampled parents and assessed uptake of HPV @hit_startvaccines@hit_end for their children (≤18 years) and/or sociodemographics, knowledge, attitudes or other factors associated with uptake. Study risk of bias was assessed using the Effective Public Health Practice Project tool. We pooled data using random-effects @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end and conducted moderation @hit_startanalyses@hit_end to examine variance in uptake by sex of child and parent. Results Seventy-nine studies on 840 838 parents across 15 countries were included. The pooled proportion of parents' uptake of HPV @hit_startvaccines@hit_end for their children was 41.5% (range: 0.7%-92.8%), twofold higher for girls (46.5%) than for boys (20.3%). In the @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end of 62 studies, physician recommendation (r=0.46 (95% CI 0.34 to 0.56)) had the greatest influence on parents' uptake, followed by HPV @hit_startvaccine@hit_end safety concerns (r=-0.31 (95% CI-0.41 to-0.16)), routine child preventive check-up, past 12 months (r=0.22 (95% CI 0.11 to 0.33)) and parents' belief in @hit_startvaccines@hit_end (r=0.19 (95% CI 0.08 to 0.29)). Health insurance-covered HPV @hit_startvaccination@hit_end (r=0.16 (95% CI 0.04 to 0.29)) and lower out-of-pocket cost (r=-0.15 (95% CI-0.22 to-0.07)) had significant effects on uptake. We found significant moderator effects for sex of child. Conclusions Findings indicate suboptimal levels of HPV @hit_startvaccine@hit_end uptake, twofold lower among boys, that may be improved by increasing physician recommendations, addressing parental safety concerns and promoting parents' positive beliefs about @hit_startvaccines@hit_end, in addition to expanding insurance coverage and reducing out-of-pocket costs. Limitations of this @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end include the lack of intervention studies and high risk of bias in most studies reviewed. Further studies should disaggregate HPV @hit_startvaccine@hit_end uptake by sex of child and parent.

titleText.ttltext: The National @hit_startVaccine@hit_end Advisory Committee at 30: Impact and opportunity

paras: Thirty years after passage of legislation that created the National @hit_startVaccine@hit_end Advisory Committee (NVAC) “to achieve optimal prevention of human infectious diseases through @hit_startimmunization@hit_end and to achieve optimal prevention against adverse reactions to @hit_startvaccines@hit_end,” this review reflects NVAC's role and impact on the U.S. @hit_startvaccine@hit_end and @hit_startimmunization@hit_end enterprise as an external advisor to the Department of Health and Human Services. We reviewed the history of NVAC in the context of the principles of its establishment, with a focus on its reports and recommendations. We performed a @hit_startsystematic literature review@hit_end to identify NVAC reports published in widely-accessible public health journals, and we reviewed the available archives to identify other reports and resolutions approved by the committee not published in journals. We characterized key issues considered by NVAC according to the five goals of the 2010 National @hit_startVaccine@hit_end Plan. The predominance of NVAC activities to date related to the implementation of @hit_startimmunization@hit_end across the lifespan and the many aspects of the system needed to foster the goal of full @hit_startimmunization@hit_end. Reflecting on the impacts of NVAC to date, this review identified 30 NVAC approved reports published in journals, 22 stand-alone resolutions, and 26 unique unpublished reports. The development of new and improved @hit_startvaccines@hit_end continues to represent a significant priority for NVAC, and we identified several challenges related to future @hit_startvaccine@hit_end innovation. Given the many factors that impact on policy changes in the @hit_startvaccine@hit_end and @hit_startimmunization@hit_end enterprise, we encountered challenges associated with demonstrating attribution of specific policy changes to NVAC recommendations. Although difficult to quantify, this review suggests that NVAC played an important role in the improvements in the U.S. @hit_startimmunization@hit_end enterprise over the past 30 years and that NVAC can and will continue to play an important role supporting U.S. @hit_startimmunization@hit_end going forward.

titleText.ttltext: New cancer cases in France in 2015 attributable to infectious agents: a @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end and @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end

organizations: Section of Cancer Surveillance, International Agency for Research on Cancer

abstracts.publisherCopyright: © 2017, Springer Science+Business Media B.V., part of Springer Nature.
paras: To provide an assessment of the burden of cancer in France in 2015 attributable to infectious agents. A @hit_startsystematic literature review@hit_end in French representative cancer cases series was undertaken of the prevalence of infectious agents with the major associated cancer types. @hit_startPubMed@hit_end was searched for original studies published up to September 2016; random-effects @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analyses@hit_end were performed. Cancer incidence data were obtained from the French Cancer Registries Network, thereby allowing the calculation of national incidence estimates. The number of new cancer cases attributable to infectious agents was calculated using population-attributable fractions according to published methods. Of the 352,000 new cancer cases in France in 2015, 14,336 (4.1% of all new cancer cases) were attributable to infectious agents. The largest contributors were human papillomavirus (HPV) and Helicobacter pylori, responsible for 6333 and 4406 new cancer cases (1.8 and 1.3% of all new cancer cases) respectively. Infectious agents caused a non-negligible number of new cancer cases in France in 2015. Most of these cancers were preventable. The expansion of @hit_startvaccination@hit_end (i.e., for hepatitis B virus and HPV) and screen-and-treat programs (for HPV and hepatitis C virus, and possibly for H. pylori) could greatly reduce this cancer burden.

ancestor: physical disease by etiology and pathogenesis
